The essay describes the attitude with which Zappettini has traversed almost 60 years of the history of art as a protagonist: a career characterised by a solitary “nomadism” deriving from his urge to explore the vast territory of painting by way of the tortuous and frequently interrupted paths suggested by constantly evolving philosophical and theoretical thinking.

Testimoni illustri come Piero Bigongiari, Lara Vinca Masini o Giovanni Michelucci hanno nel tempo affermato come qualcosa di speciale determini in Pistoia una vera e propria 'vocazione' all'arte che, per sua natura, nasce contemporanea. Il saggio si snoda come un viaggio nell'arte a Pistoia dal secondo dopoguerra attraverso le opere dell'allestimento di Palazzo De' Rossi-Fondazione Pistoia Musei, relative al progetto Pistoia Novecento. Sguardi sull'arte dal secondo dopoguerra. Oltre a configurarsi come un testo di commento alle opere esposte in questo allestimento temporaneo a lungo termine, il testo propone un approfondimento del contesto culturale pistoiese della seconda metà del secolo, a ideale integrazione del testo Cultura artistica a Pistoia dal secondo dopoguerra, pubblicato dalla stessa autrice nel volume Arte del Novecento a Pistoia , curato da Carlo Sisi (Silvana Editoriale, 2007). Una ricca selezione di documenti, provenienti da archivi d'artista e di istituzioni pubbliche e private, supporta la ricostruzione storica del periodo e arricchisce l'atlante centrale del volume creando un dialogo serrato tra opere e materiali documentari.

This study examines Bruno Munari’s work as a graphic designer from the late 1920s to mid-1940s, with the aim of understanding the emergence and characteristics of the modernist trend in Italian graphic design. Taking shape in Milan, an original ‘design culture’ eclectically brought together two quite different strains of Modernity: a local tradition represented by the Futurist avant-garde, and a European tradition associated with Constructivism. Munari (1907–1998) worked simultaneously as painter and as advertising designer. Concentrating on Munari’s stylistic development, the study seeks to explore the interaction between the Futurist visual vocabulary and conceptions coming from architecture, photography, abstract painting, and functionalist typography that trickled in from central and northern Europe. The discussion positions the designer in his time and place, concentrating as much on the artefacts as on the broader cultural framework. Secondly, the study attempts to assess Munari’s reputation against a body of exemplary work, based on firsthand documentation. It is the first extensive, detailed record of Munari’s graphic design output, and as such provides a substantial base for a full understanding of his œuvre.
